question: Question 80 Two sequences [latex]x_{1}[n] \; and \; x_{2}[n][/latex] have the same energy. Suppose [latex]x_{1}[n] = \alpha 0.5^{n} u[n] [/latex], where [latex]\alpha[/latex] is a positive real number and u[n] is the unit step sequence. Assume [latex]x_{2}[n]=\left\{\begin{matrix} \sqrt{1.5} &for n=0,1 \\ 0 & otherwise. \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] Then the value of [latex]\alpha[/latex] is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { Energy of } x_{1}[n]=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\left|x_{1}[n]\right|^{2} \\ \begin{aligned} =\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \alpha^{2} &\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{n}=\alpha^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{4}}=\alpha^{2} \cdot \frac{4}{3} \\ \text { Energy of } x_{2}[n] &=1.5+1.5=3 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \alpha^{2} \frac{4}{3} &=3 \\ \alpha^{2}=\frac{9}{4} \\ \quad \alpha=1.5 \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 81 Consider a continuous-time signal defined as [latex]x(t)=(\frac{sin(\pi t/2)}{(\pi t/2)})*\sum_{n=-\infty }^{\infty }\delta (t-10n)[/latex] where '*' denotes the convolution operation and t is in seconds. The Nyquist sampling rate (in samples/sec) for x(t) is _____.
solution: [latex]x(t)=\frac{\sin \left(\frac{\pi t}{2}\right)}{\left(\frac{\pi t}{2}\right)} * \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} \delta[t-10 n][/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} f_{\max } &=0.2 \mathrm{Hz} \\ \Rightarrow \quad f_{s} &=2 f_{\max }=0.4 \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 82 Let [latex]\tilde{x}[n]=1+cos(\frac{\pi n}{8})[/latex] be a periodic signal with period 16. Its DFS coefficients are defined by [latex]a_{k}=\frac{1}{16}\sum_{n=0}^{15}\tilde{x}[n]exp(-j\frac{\pi }{8}kn)[/latex] for all k . The value of the coefficient [latex]a_{31}[/latex] is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tilde{x}[n]&=1+\cos \left(\frac{\pi n}{8}\right)\\ &=1+\frac{e^{\left(\frac{2 \pi}{16}\right)} h}{2}+\frac{e^{-\left(\frac{2 \pi}{16}\right)}}{2} &(N=16)\\ &=1+\frac{e^{\left(\frac{2 \pi}{16}\right)}}{2}+\frac{e^{-\left(\frac{2 \pi}{16}\right)}}{2} \\ \Rightarrow a_{1}&=\frac{1}{2}\text{ and also } a_{31}=a_{15}=a_{-1}=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 83 A realization of a stable discrete time system is shown in the figure. If the system is excited by a unit step sequence input x[n], the response y[n] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{Y(z)}{X(z)}&=\frac{\frac{5}{3}[1-z]}{z^{2}-z+\frac{2}{9}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \eta (z)&=\frac{5}{3} \frac{(1-z)}{\left(z-\frac{1}{3}\right)\left(z-\frac{2}{3}\right)}\\ \eta(z) &=\frac{5 z}{z-\frac{1}{3}}-\frac{5 z}{z-\frac{2}{3}} \\ y(n) &=5\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{n} u(n)-5\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{n} u(n) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 84 Suppose x[n] is an absolutely summable discrete-time signal. Its z-transform is a rational function with two poles and two zeroes. The poles are at [latex]z = \pm 2j[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is TRUE for the signal x[n]?
solution:
Poles are at  [latex]z=\pm 2 [/latex] Since  x[n]  is absolutely summable hence, DTFT 
exists which implies ROC must include unit circle. [latex]
 \Rightarrow x(t) [/latex] is a non-causal signal.

options.A: It is a finite duration signal.

question: Question 85 Consider a four-point moving average filter defined by the equation [latex]y[n]=\sum_{i=0}^{3}\alpha _{i} x[n-i][/latex], The condition on the filter coefficients that results in a null at zero frequency is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y(n)&=\sum_{i=0}^{3} \alpha_{i} x(n-i) \\ &=\alpha_{0}x[n]+\alpha_{1} x[n-1]+\alpha_{2} x[n-2]+\alpha_{3} x[n-3] \\ \Rightarrow Y(z)&=\alpha_{0} X(z)+\alpha_{1} X(z) z^{-1}+\alpha_{2} X(z) z^{-2} \\ & +\alpha_{3} X(z) z^{-3} \\ H(z)&=\alpha_{0}+\alpha_{1} z^{-1}+\alpha_{2} z^{-2}+\alpha_{3} z^{-3} \\ \text {Null at }&\text{zero frequency } \\ \Rightarrow \quad z&=\left.e^{j \omega}\right|_{\omega=0}\\ 0 &= \alpha_{0}+\alpha_{1}+\alpha_{2}+\alpha_{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Option (A) satisfies the condition

question: Question 86 The impulse response of an LTI system can be obtained by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} IR&= \frac{d}{dt}(SR)\\ &\text{Step response,} \\ y(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{t}h(\tau )\cdot d\tau \\ h(t)&= \frac{d}{dt}y(t) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 87 The value [latex]\sum_{n=0}^{\infty }n(\frac{1}{2})^{n}[/latex] is ______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} &=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} n\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} u(n) \\ &=Z \cdot T\left[n\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} u(n)\right]_{z=1} \\ =& \frac{\frac{1}{2} Z^{-1}}{\left(1-\frac{1}{2} z^{-1}\right)^{2}}=\left.\frac{\frac{Z}{2}}{\left(z-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}}\right|_{z=1} \\ =& \frac{1 / 2}{1 / 4}=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 88 Consider the function [latex]g(t)=e^{-t}sin(2\pi t)u(t)[/latex] where u(t) is the unit step function. The area under g(t) is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} g(t) &=e^{-t} \sin (2 \pi t) u(t) \\ \text { Area } &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} g(t) d t \\ &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \sin (2 \pi t) u(t) e^{-t} d t=\left.G(s)\right|_{s=0} \\ G(s) &=\frac{2 \pi}{(s+1)^{2}+4 \pi^{2}} \\ \text { Area } &=\left.\frac{2 \pi}{(s+1)^{2}+4 \pi^{2}}\right|_{S=0}=0.155 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 89 Let [latex]x(t)=\alpha s(t)+s(-t)[/latex] with [latex] s(t)=\beta e^{-4t}u(t)[/latex], where u(t) is unit step function. If the bilateral Laplace transform of x(t) is [latex]X(s)=\frac{16}{s^{2}-16}    \; \; -4 \lt Re\lbrace s\rbrace \lt 4[/latex] ; then the value of [latex]\beta[/latex] is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t) &=\alpha \beta e^{-4 t} u(t)+\beta e^{4 t} u(-t) \\ \text { Given, } x(s) &=\frac{16}{s^{2}}-16 \quad-4 \lt \operatorname{Re}[s] \lt 4 \\ &=\frac{16}{(s+4)(s-4)}=\frac{-2}{s+4}+\frac{2}{s-4} \\ x(t)=-2 e^{-4 t} &u(t)-2 e^{4 t} u(-t) \end{aligned}[/latex] On comparison [latex]\beta=-2[/latex]

question: Question 90 Consider two real sequences with time-origin marked by the bold value, [latex]x_{1}[n]=\{1,2,3,0\}, \; \; x_{2}[n]=\{1,3,2,1\}[/latex] Let [latex]X_{1}(k) \; and \; X_{2}(k)[/latex] be 4-point DFTs of [latex]x_{1}[n] \; and \;  x_{2}[n][/latex], respectively. Another sequence [latex]x_{3}[n] [/latex] is derived by taking 4-point inverse DFT of [latex]X_{3}(k) =X_{1}(k)X_{2}(k)[/latex]. The value of [latex]x_{3}[2][/latex] is ______.
solution: [latex]x_{1}[n]=\{1,2,3,0\}, \quad x_{2}[n]=\{1,3,2,1\rangle [/latex] [latex] x(k)_{3}=x(k), \lambda(k)_{2} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow x_{3}[n]=[/latex] circular convolution of [latex]x_{1}[n][/latex] and [latex] x_{2}[n] [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=x_{1}[n] \otimes x_{2}[n] \\ \left[\begin{array}{l}x_{3}(0) \\ x_{3}(1) \\ x_{3}(2) \\ x_{3}(3)\end{array}\right]&=\left[\begin{array}{llll}1 & 0 & 3 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 & 3 \\ 3 & 2 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 & 2 & 1\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 3 \\ 2 \\ 1\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}9 \\ 8 \\ 11 \\ 14\end{array}\right] \\ x_{3}[2]&=11 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 91 Input x(t) and output y(t) of an LTI system are related by the differential equation [latex]{y}''(t)-{y}'(t)-6y(t)=x(t)[/latex] . If the system is neither causal nor stable, the impulse response h(t) of the system is
solution: [latex]y^{\prime \prime}(t)-y^{\prime}(t)-6 y(t)=x(t) [/latex] [latex] H(s)=\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=\frac{1}{s^{2}-s-6}=\frac{1}{(s-3)(s+2)} [/latex] [latex] H(s)=\frac{\left(\frac{1}{5}\right)}{s-3}+\frac{\left(-\frac{1}{5}\right)}{s+2} [/latex] If the system is neither causal nor stable, then [latex] h(t)=-\frac{1}{5} e^{3 t} u(-t)+\frac{1}{5} e^{-2 t} u(-t) \quad \mathrm{ROC}: \sigma \lt -2[/latex]

question: Question 92 Consider the differential equation [latex]\frac{dx}{dy}=10-0.2x[/latex] with initial condition x(0) =1. The response x(t) for t > 0 is
solution: Applying Laplace transform [latex] \begin{aligned} s X(s)-x(0) &=\frac{10}{s}-0.2 X(s) \\ X(s) &=\frac{10}{s(s+0.2)}+\frac{1}{(s+0.2)} \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying inverse Laplace transform, we get [latex] x=50-49 e^{(-0.2) t}[/latex]

question: Question 93 The signal [latex]cos(10\pi t+\frac{\pi }{4})[/latex] is ideally sampled at a sampling frequency of 15 Hz. The sampled signal is passed through a filter with impulse response [latex](\frac{sin(\pi t)}{\pi t})cos(40\pi t-\frac{\pi }{2})[/latex]. The filter output is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} x(t)=\cos \left(10 \pi t+\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \\ X(f)=\frac{1}{2}[\delta(f-5)+\delta(f+5)] e^{j \pi / 4} \end{array}[/latex] After sampling x(t) by 15 Hz, we get [latex] X_{s}(f)=15 \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} X(f-15 n)[/latex] Given, [latex]\quad h(t)=\left[\frac{\sin (\pi t)}{\pi t}\right] \cos \left(40 \pi t-\frac{\pi}{2}\right) [/latex] [latex] H(f)=\frac{1}{2}\left[\text{rect} \frac{(f-20)}{2 \pi}+\text{rect} \frac{(f+20)}{2 \pi}\right] e^{-j \frac{\pi}{2}} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Output }\quad Y(t)&=X_{s}(f) \times H(f) \\ y(t)&=\frac{15}{2} \cos \left(40 \pi t-\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 94 Two causal discrete-time signals x[n]and y[n] are related as [latex]y[n]=\sum_{m=0}^{n}x[m][/latex]. If the z-transform of y[n] is [latex]\frac{2}{z(z-1)^{2}}[/latex], the value of x[2] is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(n)&=\sum_{m=0}^{n} x[m]=x[n] * u[n] \\ y(z)&=X(z) \cdot\left(\frac{z}{z-1}\right)\\ \text{Given} \quad Y(z)&=\frac{2}{z(z-1)^{2}}=X(z) \cdot \frac{z}{z-1} \\ \Rightarrow \quad A(z)&=\frac{2 \cdot z^{-2}}{z-1}=2 z^{-3}\left(\frac{z}{z-1}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \quad x[n]&=2 u[n-3] \\ \text{Therefore,  } x[2]&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 95 Let the signal f(t) = 0 outside the interval [latex][T_{1}, T_{2}], [/latex] where [latex]T_{1}[/latex] and [latex]T_{2}[/latex] are finite. Furthermore,[latex]|f(t)| \lt \infty [/latex]. The region of convergence (RoC) of the signal's bilateral Laplace transform F(s) is
solution: ROC of a finite duration signal is entire s-plane.

options.A: a parallel strip containing the [latex]j\Omega[/latex] axis
options.B: a parallel strip not containing the [latex]j\Omega[/latex] axis
options.D: a half plane containing the [latex]j\Omega[/latex] axis

question: Question 96 The magnitude and phase of the complex Fourier series coefficients [latex]a_{k}[/latex] of a periodic signal x(t) are shown in the figure. Choose the correct statement from the four choices given. Notation: C is the set of complex numbers, R is the set of purely real numbers, and P is the set of purely imaginary numbers.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left|a_{k}\right|&-\text{ even symmetry} \\ \angle a_{k}&-\text{ Odd symmetry} &(\pi \text{ can be } -\pi) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow x(t) [/latex]is real.

options.D: the information given is not sufficient to draw any conclusion about x(t)

question: Question 97 The bilateral Laplace transform of a function [latex]f(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1 & if a\leq t\leq b\\ 0&otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(t)&=\left\{\begin{array}{ll} 1 & \text { if } a \leq t \leq b \\ 0 & \text { otherwise } \end{array}\right.\\ &=U(t-\mathrm{a})-(t+b) \\ \Rightarrow \quad F(s) &=\frac{e^{-a s}-e^{-b s}}{s} \end{aligned} [/latex]

question: Question 98 The pole-zero diagram of a causal and stable discrete-time system is shown in the figure. The zero at the origin has multiplicity 4. The impulse response of the system is h[n]. If h[0] = 1, we canconclude
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H(z) &=\frac{z^{4}}{\left[\left(z-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{4}\right]\left[\left(z+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{4}\right]} \\ \text { Poles } &=\frac{1}{2} \pm j \frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2} \pm j \frac{1}{2} \\ &=\frac{z^{4}}{\left(z^{2}-z+\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(z^{2}+z+\frac{1}{2}\right)} \\ &=\frac{z^{4}}{z^{4}+z^{2}+\frac{1}{4}-z^{2}}\\ H(z)&=\frac{z^{4}}{z^{4}+\frac{1}{4}} \\ &\left.=z^{4}+\frac{1}{4}\right) z^{4}\left(1-\frac{1}{4} z^{-4} \cdots\right.\\ &\quad \quad \frac{z+\frac{1}{4}}{-\frac{1}{4}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: h[n] is real for all n
options.B: h[n] is purely imaginary for all n
options.C: h[n] is real for only even n
options.D: h[n] is purely imaginary for only odd n

question: Question 99 For the discrete-time system shown in the figure, the poles of the system transfer function are located at
solution: The difference equation of the system [latex] x(n)-\frac{1}{6} y(n-2)+\frac{5}{6} y(n-1)=y(n) [/latex] [latex] H(z)=\begin{array}{l}Y(z) \\ x(z)\end{array}=\frac{1}{1+\frac{1}{6} z^{-2}-\frac{5}{6} z^{-1}} [/latex] [latex] Poles are at z=\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{3}[/latex]

question: Question 100 Two sequences [a,b,c] and [A,B,C] are related as [latex]\begin{bmatrix} A\\ B\\ C \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1& 1\\ 1& W_{3}^{-1} & W_{3}^{-2}\\ 1&W_{3}^{-2} & W_{3}^{-4} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a\\ b\\ c \end{bmatrix} \;  where\;  W_{3}=e^{j\frac{2\pi }{3}}[/latex] If another sequence [ p, q, r] is derived as, [latex]\begin{bmatrix} p\\ q\\ r \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1& 1\\ 1& W_{3}^{1} & W_{3}^{2}\\ 1&W_{3}^{2} & W_{3}^{4} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0\\ 0 & W_{3}^{2} &0 \\ 0&0 & W_{3}^{4} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} A/3\\ B/3\\ C/3\end{bmatrix}[/latex] then the relationship between the sequences [ p, q, r] and [a, b, c] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{l}A \\ B \\ C\end{array}\right]&=\left[\begin{array}{l}a+b+c \\ a+b W_{3}^{-1}+c W_{3}^{-2} \\ a+b W_{3}^{-2}+c W_{3}^{-1}\end{array}\right] \\ \left[\begin{array}{l}p \\ q \\ r\end{array}\right]&=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & w_{3}^{2} & w_{3}^{1} \\ 1 & w_{3}^{1} w_{3}^{2} & w_{3}^{2} w_{3}^{1} \\ 1 & w_{3}^{2} w_{3}^{2} & W_{3}^{1} W_{3}^{1}\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}\frac{a+b+c}{3} \\ \frac{a+b W_{3}^{-1}+c W_{3}^{2}}{3} \\ \frac{a+b W_{3}^{-2}+c W_{3}^{-1}}{3}\end{array}\right] \\ \text{where }&\quad W_{3}^{4}=e^{i \frac{2 \pi}{3}} \\ &\quad W_{3}^{2}=e^{i \frac{4 \pi}{3}}\\ W_{3}^{-1}&=e^{-j \frac{2 \pi}{3}} \\ W_{3}^{-2}&=e^{-j \frac{4 \pi}{3}} \\ W_{3}^{-4}&=W_{3}^{-1}=e^{-j \frac{2 \pi}{3}} \\ \left[\begin{array}{l}p \\q \\r\end{array}\right]&=\left[\begin{array}{l} c \\a \\b\end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 101 The waveform of a periodic signal x(t) is shown in the figure. A signal g(t) is defined by [latex]g(t)=x(\frac{t-1}{2})[/latex]. The average power of g(t) is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} x(t)=-3 t, \quad-1\lt t \lt 1 \\ x\left(\frac{t-1}{2}\right)=-\frac{3}{2}(t-1) \qquad-1 \lt t \lt 3 \\ \text { and } \quad T=6 \\ \text { Average power }=\frac{1}{6} \int_{-1}^{3}\left(-\frac{3}{2}(t-1)\right)^{2} d t=2 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 102 The result of the convolution [latex]x(-t)*\delta (-t-t_{o})[/latex]  is
solution: [latex]x(t)*\delta (-t-t_0)=x(-t)*\delta (t+t_0)=x(-t-t_0)[/latex]

question: Question 103 The N -point DFT X of a sequence x[n], [latex]0\leq n\leq N-1[/latex] is given by, [latex]X[k]=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}x[n]e^{-j\frac{2\pi }{N}nk}[/latex],   [latex]0\leq k\leq N-1[/latex] Denote this relation as [latex] X = DFT(x)[/latex]. For N=4, which one of the following sequences satisfies [latex]DFT(DFT(x)) = x [/latex]?
solution: [latex]\text { DFT }(\text{DFT}(x))=x[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Let, } x &=[123] \\ \text { DFT }(x) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4}}\left[\begin{array}{cccc}1 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -j & -1 & j \\ 1 & -1 & 1 & -1 \\ 1 & j & -1 & -j\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \\ 2\end{array}\right] \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{r}8 \\ -2 \\ 0 \\ -2\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}4 \\ -1 \\ 0 \\ -1\end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \text { DFT } (\text { DFT }(x))=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4}}\left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -j & -1 & j \\ 1 & -1 & 1 & -1 \\ 1 & j & -1 & -j \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} 4 \\ -1 \\ 0 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] \\ =\frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{l} 2 \\ 4 \\ 6 \\ 4 \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 104 A causal LTI system has zero initial conditions and impulse response [latex]h(t)[/latex]. Its
input [latex]x(t)[/latex] and output [latex]y(t)[/latex] are related through the linear constant-coefficient
differential equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}y(t)}{dt^{2}}+\alpha \frac{dy(t)}{dt}+\alpha ^{2}y(t)=x(t)[/latex] Let another signal [latex]g(t)[/latex] be defined as [latex]g(t)=\alpha ^{2}\int_{0}^{t}h(\tau )+\frac{dh(t)}{dt}+\alpha h(t)[/latex] If [latex]G(s)[/latex] is the Laplace transform of [latex]g(t)[/latex], then the number of poles of [latex]G(s)[/latex] is____.
solution: [latex]\frac{d^{2} y(t)}{d t^{2}}+\alpha \frac{d y}{d t}+\alpha^{2} y(t)=x(t) [/latex] [latex] \therefore\left(s^{2}+\alpha s+\alpha^{2}\right) Y(s)=X(s) [/latex] [latex] H(s)=\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=\frac{1}{\left(s^{2}+\alpha s+\alpha^{2}\right)} [/latex] Let another signal g(t) be defined as [latex] \begin{aligned} G(s)&=\frac{\alpha^{2}}{s} H(s)+s H(s)+\alpha H(s) \\ G(s) &=\left(\frac{\alpha^{2}}{s}+s+\alpha\right) H(s) \\ =&\left(\frac{\alpha^{2}+s^{2}+s \alpha}{s}\right) \cdot\left(s^{2}+\alpha s+\alpha^{2}\right) \\ =& \frac{\left(s^{2}+s \alpha+a^{2}\right)}{s\left(s^{2}+\alpha s+\alpha^{2}\right)}=\frac{1}{s} \end{aligned} [/latex] So, number of poles of G(s) is 1

question: Question 105 A stable linear time invariant (LTI) system has a transfer function [latex]H(S)=\frac{1}{s^{2}+s-6}[/latex]. To make this system causal it needs to be cascaded with another LTI system having a transfer function [latex]H_{1}(S)[/latex]. A correct choice for [latex]H_{1}(S)[/latex] among the following options is
solution: [latex]H(s)=\frac{1}{\left(s^{2}+s-6\right)}[/latex] The system is said to be causal if the output at  any time depends only on present and/or past values of input or [latex] h(t)=0[/latex] for [latex]t \gt 0[/latex] i.e. all poles must lie on LHS of S-plane. [latex] H(s)=\frac{1}{(s+3)(s-2)}[/latex] From the above expression it can be seen that s=2 is a pole which lies on RHS of s-plane. So, [latex] H_{1}(s)[/latex] system that needs to be cascaded should have one zero at (s-2) [latex] \text { Thus, } H(s) H_{1}(s)=(s-2) \cdot \frac{1}{(s+3)(s-2)}  =\frac{1}{(s+3)} \rightarrow \text { causal system } [/latex]

question: Question 106 The unilateral Laplace transform of [latex]f (t)[/latex] is [latex]\frac{1}{s^{2}+s+1}[/latex]. Which one of the following is the unilateral Laplace transform of [latex]g(t) = t \cdot f(t) [/latex]?
solution: Given [latex]F(s)=\frac{1}{s^{2}+s+1} [/latex] Laplace transform of [latex]g(t)=t \cdot f(t) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=-\frac{d F(s)}{d s}=\frac{-d}{d s}\left[\frac{1}{\left(s^{2}+s+1\right)}\right] \\ &=\frac{(2 s+1)}{\left(s^{2}+s+1\right)^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 107 The sequence [latex]x[n]=0.5^{n}u[n][/latex], where u[n] is the unit step sequence, is convolved with itself to obtain y[n]. Then [latex]\sum_{n=-\infty }^{+\infty }y[n][/latex] is _____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given } x[n] &=0.5^{n} u[n] \\ y[n] &=x[n] * x[n] \\ &=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty} x(k) h(n-k)\\ &=\sum_{K=-\infty}^{\infty}(0.5)^{k} u(k)(0.5)^{n-k} u(n-k) \\ &=(0.5)^{n}\left[\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty} u(k) u(n-k)\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] Also we know that [latex] u[n] * u[n]=(n+1) u[n] [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Using the above formula, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} y[n]&=(0.5)^{n}(n+1) u[n] \\ \text{Let }p&=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(0.5)^{n}(n+1) \\ \text{Also let }a&=0.5 \\ \therefore \quad p&=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a^{n}(n+1) \\ \rho&=a^{0}(1)+a^{1}(1+1)+a^{2}(2+1)+a^{3}(3+1)+\ldots \\ a p&=a(1)+a^{2}(2)+a^{3}(3)+\cdots \\ p-a p&=a^{0} \cdot 1+a^{1}+a^{2}+\cdots \\ p(1-a)&=\frac{1}{1-a} \\ p&=\frac{1}{(1-a)^{2}} \\ a&=0.5 \text{ or } \frac{1}{2} \\ p&=\frac{1}{\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{1}{\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}}=4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 108 A real-valued signal x(t) limited to the frequency band [latex]|f|\leq \frac{W}{2}[/latex] is passed through a linear time invariant system whose frequency response is [latex]H(f)=\left\{\begin{matrix} e^{-j4\pi f}, &|f|\leq \frac{W}{2} \\ 0, & |f|> \frac{W}{2} \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] The output of the system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given:} \quad H(f)&=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}e^{-j 4 \pi t}, & |f| \leq \frac{\omega}{2} \\ 0, & |f|>\frac{\omega}{2}\end{array}\right. \\ \text{So, } \quad|H(t)|&=1 \\ H(f)&=e^{-j 2.2 \pi t} \\ H(\omega)&=e^{j 2 \omega} &|f| \leq \frac{\omega}{2} \\ h(t)&=\delta(t-2)\\ \text{As we know that}\\ y(t)&=x(t) * h(t)\\ \text{or}\quad y(t)&=X(\omega) \cdot H(\omega) \\ y(t)&=x(t) * \delta(t-2) \\ y(t)&=x(t-2) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 109 A Fourier transform pair is given by [latex](\frac{2}{3})^{n}  \; u[n+3]\overset{FT}{\leftrightarrow}\frac{Ae^{-j6\pi f}}{1-(\frac{2}{3})e^{-j2 \pi f}}[/latex] where u [n] denotes the unit step sequence. The values of A is _____.
solution:
[latex]\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{n} u(n+3) \stackrel{F.T.}{\longleftrightarrow} \frac{Ae^{j6\pi f}}{1-\left(\frac{2}{3}\right) e^{-i 2 \pi f}}[/latex] Let, [latex] x[n]=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{n} u(n+3) [/latex] Discrete Fourier transform is given as [latex] \begin{aligned} X\left(e^{j \omega}\right)&=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} x[n] e^{-j \omega n} \\ &=\sum_{n=-3}^{\infty}\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{n} e^{-j \omega n} \\ \text { Put, } n+3 &=m \\ \text { So, } x\left(e^{i \omega}\right) &=\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{m-3} e^{-j \omega(m-3)} \\ &=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{-3} \sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{m} e^{-j \omega m \cdot e^{j \omega 3}} \\
&=\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)^{3} \sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{2}{3} e^{-j \omega}\right)^{m} \cdot e^{j \omega 3} \\
&=\frac{3.375 \cdot e^{i 2 \pi / 3}}{1-\frac{2}{3} e^{-i 2 \pi t}} \\
&=\frac{3.375 e^{j \pi \pi f}}{1-\frac{2}{3} e^{-i 2 \pi t}} \\
\text{So,}\quad A&=3.375
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 110 For a given sample-and-hold circuit, if the value of the hold capacitor is increased, then
solution: We know that [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=C V=i \cdot t &\ldots(i)\\ t&=\frac{C V}{i} &\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] From equation (ii) [latex] t \propto C[/latex] and it is clear that if value of capacitor increases then the acquisition time increases. For capacitor the drop rate is given as [latex]\frac{d v}{d t} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} i &=C \frac{d v}{d t} \\ \frac{d v}{d t} &=\frac{i}{C} \\ \frac{d v}{d t} & \propto \frac{1}{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] From above relation it is clear that if capacitor value  increases drop rate decreases.

options.A: droop rate decreases and acquisition time decreases
options.B: droop rate decreases and acquisition time increases
options.C: droop rate increases and acquisition time decreases
options.D: droop rate increases and acquisition time increases

question: Question 111 The z-transform of the sequence x[n] is given by [latex]X(z)=\frac{1}{(1-2z^{-1})^{2}}[/latex], with the region of convergence |z| > 2. Then, x[2] is ____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given, }\quad X(z)&=\frac{1}{\left(1-2 z^{-1}\right)^{2}}, \quad|Z| \gt 2 \\ X(z)&=\left(1-2 z^{1}\right)^{-2} \\ X(z)&=1+4 z^{-1}+12 z^{-2}+\cdots\\ &\quad \quad \text{(using binomial expansion)} \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking inverse z-transform, we get [latex] \therefore \quad x[n]=\left\{\begin{array}{lll}1, & 4, & 12,\end{array} \cdots\right. [/latex] [latex] x[2]=12[/latex]

question: Question 112 Let h(t) denote the impulse response of a causal system with transfer function [latex]\frac{1}{s+1}[/latex]. Consider the following three statements. S1 : The system is stable S2: [latex]\frac{h(t+1)}{h(t)}[/latex] is independent of [latex]t \gt 0[/latex] S3 : A non-causal system with the same transfer function is stable For the above system
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given } H(s)&=\frac{1}{(s+1)} \\ h(t)&=e^{-t} u(t) \\ \text { at } t&=\infty, h(t)=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] i.e. the system is stable as it converges to zero as [latex]t \rightarrow \infty [/latex] The system is causal as it can be seen from  the graph that [latex]h(t)=0[/latex] for [latex]t \lt 0 [/latex] [latex] \frac{h(t+1)}{h(t)}=\frac{e^{-(t+1)}}{e^{-t}}=\frac{e^{-t} \cdot e^{-1}}{e^{-t}} [/latex] [latex] =e^{-1}[/latex] i.e. independent of t So, statements [latex]S_{1}[/latex] and [latex]S_{2}[/latex] are true

options.A: only S1 and S2 are true
options.B: only S2 and S3 are true
options.C: only S1 and S3 are true

question:
Question 113 Let [latex]H_{1}(z)=(1-pz^{-1})^{-1}[/latex], [latex]H_{2}(z)=(1-qz^{-1})^{-1}[/latex], [latex]H(z)=H_{1}(z)+rH_{2}(z)[/latex]. The
quantities [latex]p, q, r [/latex] are real numbers. Consider [latex]p=\frac{1}{2}, q=-\frac{1}{4},|r|\lt 1[/latex]. If the zero of [latex]H(z)[/latex] lies on the unit circle, then [latex]r[/latex] = ____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Here } H_1(z)&=\frac{1}{1-pz^{-1}} \\ H_2(z)&= \frac{1}{1-qz^{-1}}\\ \text{also } p&=\frac{1}{2},\; q=-\frac{1}{4} \\ \therefore \; H(z)&=H_1(z)+rH_2(z) \\ &= \frac{1}{1-pz^{-1}}+\frac{r}{1-qz^{-1}}\\ &= \frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{2}z^{-1}}+\frac{r}{1+\frac{1}{4}z^{-1}}\\ H(z)&=\frac{\left ( 1+\frac{1}{4}z^{-1} \right )+r\left ( 1-\frac{1}{2}z^{-1} \right )}{\left ( 1-\frac{1}{2}z^{-1} \right )\left ( 1+\frac{1}{4}z^{-1} \right )}\;\;...(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] zero of [latex]H(z) \Rightarrow [/latex] [latex] (1+r)-(q+p r) z^{-1}=0 \; \; ...(ii)[/latex] or [latex]\quad z=\frac{q+p r}{1+r} [/latex] Since, the zero of H(z) lies on the unit circle therefore [latex]|z|=1[/latex] or [latex] z=\pm 1 [/latex] Taking z=1, we get [latex] z=\frac{q+p r}{1+r}=1 \; \; ...(iii)[/latex] By solving above expression with [latex]p=\frac{1}{2}[/latex] and [latex] q=-\frac{1}{4},[/latex] we get [latex] r=-2.5[/latex] But [latex]|r| \lt 1 \quad [/latex] or [latex]\quad-1 \lt r \lt 1 [/latex] Taking z=-1 in equation (iii), we get [latex] r=-0.5[/latex]

question: Question 114 The phase response of a passband waveform at the receiver is given by [latex]\varphi (f)=-2\pi \alpha (f-f_{c})-2\pi \beta f_{c}[/latex] where [latex]f_{c}[/latex] is the centre frequency, and [latex]\alpha[/latex] and [latex]\beta[/latex] are positive constants. The actual signal propagation delay from the transmitter to receiver is
solution: Group delay is given by [latex] =\frac{-1}{2 \pi} \frac{d \phi(f)}{d f}=\frac{-1}{2 \pi}[-2 \pi \alpha][/latex] Group delay [latex]=\alpha[/latex]

question:
Question 115 The input [latex]-3e^{2t}u(t)[/latex], where u(t) is the unit step function, is applied to a
system with transfer function [latex]\frac{s-2}{s+3}[/latex]. If the initial value of the output is -2, then the value of the output at steady state is _____.
solution: Given, [latex] x(t)=-3 e^{-2 t} [/latex] Laplace transform of [latex] x(t) \longleftrightarrow X(s)[/latex] Where, [latex] \begin{aligned} X(s) &=\frac{-3}{s+2} \\ A \mid s 0, H(s) &=\frac{s-2}{(s+3)} \\ \therefore \quad Y(s) &=X(s) H(s) \\ \gamma(s) &=\frac{-3(s-2)}{(s+3)(s+2)} \end{aligned}[/latex] Using final value theorem, the steady state value of Y(s) is [latex] \begin{aligned} y(\infty) &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s Y(s) \\ &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 116 For an all-pass system [latex]H(z)=\frac{(z^{-1}-b)}{(1-az^{-1})}[/latex], where [latex]|H(e^{-j\omega })|=1[/latex], for all [latex]\omega[/latex]. If Re[latex](a)\neq 0[/latex], Im[latex](a)\neq 0[/latex], then b equals
solution: For the given system [latex] H(z)=\frac{\left(z^{-1}-b\right)}{\left(1-a z^{-1}\right)}[/latex] The pole lie at z=a and the zero lie at [latex]z=\frac{1}{b} [/latex] also 'a' is complex in nature. Thus, [latex]a=|a| e^{i \lt a}[/latex] For an all pass system where [latex]\left|\mathrm{H}\left(e^{-k \mathrm{o}}\right)\right|=1,[/latex] for all [latex] \omega,[/latex] if the pole lies at 'a' then the zero must be present at [latex]\frac{1}{a^{*}} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad\left(\frac{1}{b}\right)&=\frac{1}{|a| e^{-j \lt a}}=\frac{1}{a^{*}} \\ \text{ or} \quad b&=a^{*} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 117 Let [latex]x(t)=cos(10\pi t)+cos(30\pi t)[/latex] be sampled at 20 Hz and reconstructed
using an ideal low-pass filter with cut-off frequency of 20 Hz. The frequency/
frequencies present in the reconstructed signal is/are
solution: [latex]x(t)=\cos (10 \pi t)+\cos (30 \pi t)[/latex] Given sampling frequency, [latex]f_{s}=20 \mathrm{Hz} [/latex] [latex] \omega_{s}=40 \pi \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec}[/latex] [latex] Y(\omega)=\sum_{K=-\infty}^{\infty} X\left(\omega-K \omega_{s}\right)[/latex] After sampling waveform will be Applying an ideal low-pass filter of cut-off frequency of [latex]20 \mathrm{Hz}[/latex] or [latex]40 \pi \; \mathrm{ rad} / \mathrm{sec},[/latex] we get the frequencies in reconstructed signal as [latex] 10 \pi \text{ and } 30 \pi \; \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec}[/latex]. or [latex] 5 \mathrm{Hz}[/latex] and [latex]15 \mathrm{Hz}[/latex]

question: Question 118 The value of the integral [latex]\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }sinc^{2}(5t)dt[/latex] is ____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \sin c^{2}(5 t) d t \\ \text { Let, } \quad f(t)&=\sin c(5 t) \\ \quad&=S_{a}(5 \pi t) \; \; \; [\because \sin c(t)=S a(\pi t)] \\ T S a\left(t \cdot \frac{T}{2}\right) &\longleftrightarrow 2 \pi G_{T}(\omega) \\ \quad \frac{T}{2}&=5 \pi \Rightarrow[T=10 \pi] \\ 10 \pi S a(5 \pi t) &\longleftrightarrow 2 \pi G_{10 \pi}(\omega) \\ \Rightarrow \quad F(\omega)&=\frac{1}{5} G_{10 \pi}(\omega)\\ E S D_{f}&=|F(\omega)|^{2} \\ E_{f}&=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f^{2}(t) d t=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} E S D_{f} d \omega \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \sin c^{2}(5 t) d t &=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-5 \pi}^{5 \pi}\left(\frac{1}{5}\right)^{2} d \omega \\ &=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \times \frac{1}{25} \times 10 \pi=\frac{1}{5} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 119 The input-output relationship of a causal stable LTI system is given as [latex]y[n] = \alpha[/latex] y[n -1]+ [latex]\beta x[n][/latex] If the impulse response h[n] of this system satisfies the condition [latex]\sum_{n=0}^{\infty }h[n]=2[/latex],  the relationship between [latex]\alpha[/latex] and [latex]\beta[/latex] is
solution: Input-output relation is given as [latex] \begin{aligned} y[n]&=\alpha_{\mathcal{Y}}(n-1)+\beta x[n] \\ \text{Taking Z-transform, }\\ r(z)&=\alpha z^{-1} \quad Y (z)+\beta X(z) \\ Y(z)&\left[1-\alpha z^{-1}\right]=\beta X(z) \\ \frac{\gamma(z)}{X(z)}&=H(z)=\frac{\beta}{1-\alpha z^{-1}} \\ h[n]&=\beta \cdot \alpha^{n} u[n] \\ \text{Also }&\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} h[n]=2 \Rightarrow \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \beta \cdot \alpha^{n} u[n]=2 \\ \frac{\beta}{1-\alpha}&=2 \Rightarrow \beta=2-2 \alpha \\ \Rightarrow 2 a &=2-\beta \\ \alpha &=1-\frac{\beta}{2} \end{aligned} [/latex]

question: Question 120 Consider a discrete-time signal [latex]x[n]=\left\{\begin{matrix} n & for \; 0\leq n\leq 10\\ 0&otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] If y[n] is the convolution of x[n] with itself, the value of y[4] is _____.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} x[n]=\left\{\begin{array}{ll} n & \text { for } 0 \leq n \leq 10 \\ 0 & \text { otherwise } \end{array}\right. \\ y[n]=\sum_{K=\infty}^{\infty} x(k) x(n-k) \\ y[4]=\sum_{k=0}^{10} x(k) x(4-k) \\ =x(0) x(4)+x(1) x(3)+x(2) x(2)+x(3) x(1)+0 \\ =0+(1 \times 3)+(2 \times 2)+(3 \times 1) \\ =10 \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 121 Consider the periodic square wave in the figure shown. The ratio of the power in the [latex]7^{th}[/latex] harmonic to the power in the [latex]5^{th}[/latex] harmonic for
this waveform is closest in value to ______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} X(\omega) &=\sum_{K=-\infty}^{\infty} 2 \pi a_{k} \delta\left(0-K \omega\right) \\ a_{K} &=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2} x(t) e^{-j K \omega_{0} t} d t \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\left\{\int_{0}^{1} 1 \cdot e^{-j K \omega_{o} t} d \omega-\int_{1}^{2} 1 \cdot e^{-j K \omega_{o} t} d \omega\right\}\\ &=\frac{1}{2\pi}\left[\frac{1}{-j K \omega_{o}}[e^{-j K \omega_{o}}-1]-\frac{1}{-j K \omega_{o}}[e^{(-j 2K \omega_{o})}-e^{(-j 2K \omega_{o})}] \right ]\\ &=\frac{1}{2\pi}\left[\frac{e^{-j K \omega_{o}l2}}{j K \omega_{o}}.2j\sin\frac{K\omega_{o}}{2}-\frac{1}{j K \omega_{o}}e^{-\frac{j K \omega_{o}3}{2}}\left(2j\sin\frac{K\omega_{0}}{2} \right ) \right ]\\ &=\frac{1}{\pi}\left[\frac{\sin \frac{K \omega_{o}}{2}}{K \omega_{o}}\left(e^{-j K \omega_{0}}\right)\left(e^{\frac{j K \omega_{0}}{2}}-e^{-\frac{K_{m_{2}}}{2}}\right)\right] \\ &=\frac{1}{\pi}\left(\frac{\sin K \omega_{0} / 2}{K \omega_{o}}\right) e^{-j K \omega_{0}} \times 2 j \sin \left(\frac{\left.K_{\left(0_{0}\right.}\right)}{2}\right) \\ &=\frac{1}{\pi^{2}} \frac{\left(\sin K \frac{\pi}{2}\right)^{2}}{K} 2 j \times \cos K \pi \end{aligned}\\[/latex] [latex]7^{\text {th }}[/latex] harmonic power [latex]=\left(2 \pi a_{7}\right)^{2} [/latex] [latex] 5^{\text {th }}[/latex] harmonic power [latex]=\left(2 \pi a_{5}\right)^{2} [/latex] [latex] Ratio =\left(\frac{a_{7}}{a_{5}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{5}{7}\right)^{2}=\frac{25}{49}=0.51[/latex]

question:
Question 122 Let x[n] = x[-n]. Let X(z) be the z -transform of x[n]. If 0.5+j0.25 is a zero of
X(z), which one of the following must also be a zero of X(z).
solution: Given [latex]x[n]=x[-n] [/latex] As we know that, [latex] \begin{aligned} x[n] & \stackrel{Z}{\longleftrightarrow} X[z] \\ x[-n] & \stackrel{Z}{\longleftrightarrow} X\left[z^{-1}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] So, when [latex](0.5+j 0.25)[/latex] is a zero of X(z). Now [latex]x[-n] \longleftrightarrow X\left(z^{-1}\right) [/latex] Zero of [latex]X(z)=\frac{1}{(0.5+j 0.25)}[/latex]

question: Question 123 An FIR system is described by the system function [latex]H(z)=1+\frac{7}{2}z^{-1}+\frac{3}{2}z^{-2}[/latex] The system is
solution:
Minimum phase  [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex]  all zeroes are inside the unit 
circle. For maximum phase, all the zeroes are outside 
the unit circle. [latex]
 H(z)=1+\frac{7}{2} z^{-1}+\frac{3}{2} z^{-2}=0 [/latex] [latex]
 2 z^{2}+6 z+z+3=0 [/latex] [latex]
 (2 z+1)(z+3)=0 [/latex] [latex]
 z_{1}=-\frac{1}{2}[/latex]  (inside the unit circle) [latex]
 z_{2}=-3[/latex]  (outside the unit circle) [latex]
 \therefore [/latex] Mixed phase.

question:
Question 124 A system is described by the following differential equation, where u(t) is the
input to the system and y(t) is the output of the system. [latex]\dot{y}(t)+5y(t)=u(t)[/latex] when y(0) = 1 and u(t)  is a unit step function, y(t)  is
solution: [latex]\dot{y}(t)+5 y(t)=u(t) [/latex] Taking the Laplace transform of the above equation [latex] \begin{aligned} s Y(s)-y(0)+5 & r(s)=\frac{1}{s} \\ (s+5) r(s)-1 & =\frac{1}{s} \\ (s+5) r(s) & =\frac{s+1}{s} \\ Y(s) & =\frac{(s+1)}{s(s+5)} \\ \frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{(s+5)} & =\frac{(s+1)}{s(s+5)} \\ A&=0.2 \\ B&=\frac{-4}{-5}=0.8 \\ r(s) &=\frac{0.2}{s}+\frac{0.8}{(s+5)}\\ y(t)&=0.2+0.8 e^{-5 t} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 125 Consider a discrete time periodic signal [latex]x[n]=sin(\frac{\pi n}{5})[/latex]. Let [latex]a_{k}[/latex] be the complex Fourier series coefficients of x[n]. The coefficients [latex]\{a_{k}\}[/latex] are non-zero when
k = Bm[latex]{\pm }[/latex]1, where m is any integer. The value of B is ____.
solution: From discrete Fourier series definition [latex] \begin{array}{l} x[n]=\sum_{K=0}^{N-1} a_{K} e^{j K\left(\frac{2 \pi}{N}\right) n}\\ =a_{-1} e^{-j \frac{2 \pi}{N} n}+a_{0}+a_{1} e^{i \frac{2 \pi}{N} n} \quad \ldots(i)\\ x[n]=\frac{-1}{2 j} e^{-i \frac{\pi}{5} n}+\frac{1}{2 j} e^{i \frac{\pi}{5} n} \end{array}[/latex] Also given [latex] x[n]=\sin \left(\frac{\pi n}{5}\right) [/latex] where [latex] N=10\left[\frac{2 \pi}{N}=\frac{\pi}{5} \Rightarrow N=10\right] [/latex] By comparison [latex]a_{1}=\frac{1}{2 j} and a_{9}=a_{-1}=\frac{-1}{2 j} [/latex] As the TFS coefficient [latex]a_{K}[/latex] is also periodic with period N=10. [latex] \begin{aligned} a_{1} &=a_{11}=a_{21} \cdots \\ a_{-1} &=a_{9}=a_{19} \cdots \end{aligned}[/latex] Given that [latex]a_{K}[/latex] is non-zero for [latex]K=B m \pm 1 [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{cc} B m \pm 1=1& \quad 9 \cdots\\ -1 &\quad11\ldots\\ \text{For }m=0 \quad for& \quad m=1 \\ \end{array}[/latex] To satisfy this condition B must be '10' where 'm'  is any integer.

question: Question 126 Let [latex]x[n]=(-\frac{1}{9})^{n} u(n)-(-\frac{1}{3})^{n} u(-n-1)[/latex]. The Region of Convergence (ROC) of the z -transform of x[n].
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(n) &=\frac{\left(-\frac{1}{9}\right)^{n} u(n)-\left(-\frac{1}{3}\right)^{n} u(-n-1)}{x_{1}(n)} \frac{1}{x_{2}(n)} \\ x_{1}(n) &=\left(-\frac{1}{9}\right)^{n} u(n) \rightarrow \text { Right sided signal } \\ x_{1}(z) &=\frac{1}{1-\left(-\frac{1}{9}\right) z^{-1}} \\ \operatorname{ROC}|z| & \geq\left|\frac{1}{9}\right| \text { or }|z|>\frac{1}{9} \\ x_{2}(n) &=\left(-\frac{1}{3}\right)^{n} u(-n-1) \rightarrow \text { Left sided signal } \\ x_{2}(z) &=\frac{1}{1-\left(-\frac{1}{3}\right) z^{-1}} ; \quad|z| \leq \frac{1}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now, when both the transforms are added using linearity property. ROC must be between [latex] \frac{1}{3}>|z|>\frac{1}{9}[/latex]

question: Question 127 For a function g(t), it is given that [latex]\int_{-\infty }^{+\infty }g(t)e^{-j\omega t}dt=\omega e^{-2\omega ^{2}}[/latex] for any real value [latex]\omega[/latex]. If [latex]y(t)=\int_{-\infty }^{t}g(\tau)d\tau[/latex] , then [latex]\int_{-\infty }^{+\infty }y(t)dt[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G(j \omega) &=\omega e^{-2 \omega^{2}} \\ \int_{-\infty}^{*} g(t) d t &=G(j 0)=0 \\ y(t) &=g(t) * u(t) \\ \Rightarrow \quad r(j \omega) &=G(j \omega) U(j \omega) \\ \Rightarrow \quad \gamma(j \omega) &=G(j \omega)\left[\frac{1}{j \omega}+\pi \delta(\omega)\right] \\ &=\frac{\omega e^{-2 \omega^{2}}}{j \omega}+\omega e^{-2 \omega^{2}} \pi \delta(\omega) \\ \int_{-\infty}^{*} y(t) d t &=Y(j 0)=\frac{1}{j}=-j \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 128 A continuous, linear time-invariant filter has an impulse response h(t) described
by [latex]h(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} 3 &for \; 0\leq t\leq 3 \\ 0&otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] When a constant input of values 5 is applied to this filter, the steady state output is_____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h(t) &=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}3, & \text { for } 0 \leq t \leq 3 \\0, & \text { otherwise } \end{array}\right.\\ h(t) &=3[u(t)-u(t-3)] \\ H(s) &=3\left[\frac{1}{s}-\frac{e^{-3 s}}{s}\right] \\ \therefore \quad x(t) &=5 \\ \text { Then } x(s) &=\frac{5}{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] We know that [latex] Y(s)=H(s) X(s)=3\left[\frac{1}{s}-\frac{e^{-3 s}}{s}\right] \cdot \frac{5}{s} [/latex] Steady state output [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s \cdot Y(s)=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s \cdot \frac{15}{s} \frac{\left(1-e^{-3 s}\right)}{s} \\ =15 \cdot \lim _{s \rightarrow 0} 3 e^{-3 s} \quad[\because \quad \text { L-Hospital's rule }] \\ \quad=45 \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 129 Consider two real valued signals, x(t) band-limited to [-500 Hz, 500 Hz] and
y(t) band-limited to [-1 kHz, 1 kHz]. For [latex]z(t) = x(t)\cdot  y(t)[/latex], the Nyquist sampling
frequency (in kHz) is ____.
solution: Multiplication in time domain = convolution in frequency domain. [latex] x_{1}(t) \cdot x_{2}(t) \leftrightarrow X_{1}(\omega) * X_{2}(\omega) [/latex] So, highest frequency component contained by the convolved signal [latex]z(t)=1500 \mathrm{Hz} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Nyquist rate [latex]=2 \times 1500 [/latex] [latex] =3000 \mathrm{Hz}=3 \mathrm{kHz}[/latex]

question: Question 130 A discrete time signal [latex]x[n]=sin(\pi ^{2 }n)[/latex], [latex] n[/latex] being an integer, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x[n] &=\sin \left(\pi^{2} n\right) \\ \omega_{0} &=\pi^{2} \\ \therefore \quad N &=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega_{0}} \cdot m \end{aligned}[/latex] where m is the smallest integer that converts [latex]\frac{2 \pi}{\omega_{0}}[/latex] into a integer value. [latex] \therefore \quad N=\frac{2 \pi}{\pi^{2}} \cdot m=\frac{2}{\pi} \cdot m [/latex] So, there exists no such integer value of m which could make the N integer, so the system is not periodic.

question: Question 131 The DFT of a vector [a b c d] is the vector [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \alpha & \beta & \gamma &\delta \end{bmatrix}[/latex]. Consider the product [latex]\begin{bmatrix} p &q &r &s\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} a &b &c &d \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} a &b &c &d \\ d &a &b & c\\ c& d &a &b \\ b&c &d &a \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The DFT of the vector [latex]\begin{bmatrix} p &q &r &s \end{bmatrix}[/latex] is a scaled version of
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \operatorname{DFT}[\rho q r s] &=[a b c d] *[a b c d] \\ \text { So, DFT }[p q r s] &=\left[\alpha^{2} \beta^{2} \gamma^{2} \delta^{2}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 132 A system is described by the differential equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}y}{dt^{2}}+5\frac{dy}{dt}+6y (t)=x(t)[/latex] Let [latex] x(t )[/latex] be a rectangular pulse given by [latex]x(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1 & o \lt t \lt 2 \\ 0 & otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] Assuming that y(0) = 0 and [latex]\frac{dy}{dt}=0[/latex] at t = 0, the Laplace transform of y(t) is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} x(t)=u(t)-u(t-2) \\ X(s)=\frac{1}{s}-\frac{e^{-2 s}}{s}=\frac{1-e^{-2 s}}{s} \end{array}[/latex] Given that [latex] \frac{d^{2} y}{d t^{2}}+5 \frac{d y}{d t}+6 y(t)=x(t) [/latex] Taking Laplace transform on both the sides [latex] \begin{array}{l} \left(y(0)=0 \text { and } \frac{d y}{d t}=0 \text { at } t=0\right)\\ \left.s^{2} \eta s\right)+5 s Y(s)+6 Y(s)=x(s) \\ Y(s)\left[s^{2}+5 s+6\right]=\frac{1-e^{-2 s}}{s}\\ Y(s)=\frac{1-e^{-2 s}}{s\left(s^{2}+5 s+6\right)}=\frac{1-e^{-2 s}}{s(s+2)(s+3)} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 133 The impulse response of a continuous time system is given by [latex]h(t)= \delta (t-1)+\delta (t-3)[/latex]. The value of the step response at t = 2 is
solution: Step response = Integration of impulse response [latex] \int_{-\infty}^{t} \delta(t-1) d t=u(t-1) [/latex] [latex] \int_{-\infty}^{t} \delta(t-3) d t=u(t-3) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{at}\quad t&=2\\ y(t)&=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 134 Assuming zero initial condition, the response y(t) of the system given below to a unit step input u(t) is
solution: [latex]x(t)=u(t)[/latex] Apply Laplace transform [latex] \begin{aligned} X(s) &=\frac{1}{s} \\ H(s) &=\frac{1}{s} \quad(\text { given }) \\ Y(s) &=H(s) X(s) \\ &=\frac{1}{s} \times \frac{1}{s}=\frac{1}{s^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking inverse Laplace transform [latex] y(t)=t u(t)[/latex]

question: Question 135 Which one of the following statements is NOT TRUE for a continuous time causal and stable LTI system?
solution:
For a causal and stable LTI system the ROC must be right sided and it must include the [latex] s=j \omega [/latex] line [latex] (\sigma=0) [/latex]. For all the poles must lie within [latex] |s|=1 [/latex] then all poles will lie between -1 to +1. We know that ROC does not include any pole, so in this case ROC will not be able to include [latex] s= j0[/latex]  line [latex] (\sigma=0) . [/latex] Thus the system will not be stable. Hence, 
this statement is NOT TRUE.

options.A: All the poles of the system must lie on the left side of the [latex]j\omega[/latex] axis.
options.B: Zeros of the system can lie anywhere in the s-plane.
options.C: All the poles must lie within [latex]\left | s \right |=1[/latex]
options.D: All the roots of the characteristic equation must be located on the left side of the [latex]j\omega[/latex] axis.

question: Question 136 A band-limited signal with a maximum frequency of 5 kHz is to be sampled. According to the sampling theorem, the sampling frequency which is not valid is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left(f_{s}\right)_{\min } &=2 f_{m} \\ \left(f_{s}\right)_{\min } &=2 \times 5=10 \mathrm{kHz} \\ \mathrm{So}, \quad f_{s} & \geq 10 \mathrm{kHz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 137 For a periodic signal [latex]v\left ( t \right )=30\sin 100t+10\cos 300t+6\sin \left ( 500t+\frac{\pi }{4} \right )[/latex], the fundamental frequency in rad/s is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \omega_{1}=100 \\ \omega_{2}=300 \\ \omega_{3}=500 \end{array}[/latex] H.C.F. of [latex]\left(\omega_{1}, \omega_{2} \text { and } \omega_{3}\right)=[/latex] H.C.F. (100,300,500) [latex] \omega=100 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec}[/latex]

question: Question 138 The impulse response of a system is [latex]h\left ( t \right )= tu\left ( t \right )[/latex]. For an input u(t-1), the output is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h(t)&=t u(t) \\ \text{Taking }&\text{Laplace transform}\\ H(s)&=\frac{1}{s^{2}} \\ x(t) &=u(t-1) \\ \text { Taking }&\text{Laplace transform } \\ X(s)&=\frac{e^{-s}}{s} \\ \frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}&=H(s) \\ Y(s)&=H(s) X(s) \\ Y(s)&=\frac{1}{s^{2}} \cdot \frac{e^{-s}}{s}=\frac{e^{-s}}{s^{3}} \\ \text{Taking } &\text{the inverse Laplace transform } \\ y(t)&=\frac{(t-1)^{2}}{2} u(t-1) \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 139 Two systems with impulse responses [latex]h_{1}\left ( t \right )[/latex] and [latex]h_{2}\left ( t \right )[/latex] are connected in cascade. Then the overall impulse response of the cascaded system is given by
solution:
The overall impulse response h(t) of the cascade 
system is given by: [latex]
h(t)=h_{1}(t) * h_{2}(t)[/latex]

question: Question 140 Let y[n] denote the convolution of h[n] and g[n], where [latex]h[n]=(1/2)^{n}u[n][/latex] and g[n] is a causal sequence. If y[0] = 1 and y[1] = 1/2, then g[1] equals
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h[n]&=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} u[n] \\ g[n]&=? ? \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] y[n]=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty} h[n-k] g[k] [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} y[0] &=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty} h(-k] g[k] \\ y[0] &=h[0] g[0] \\ 1 &=1 g[0] \\ g[0] &=1 \\ y[1] &=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty} h(1-k] g[k] \\ y[1] &=h[1] g(0]+h[0] g(1] \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] h[1-k][/latex] will be zero for [latex]k \gt 1[/latex] and [latex]g[k][/latex] will be z for [latex]k \lt 0[/latex] as it is causal sequence. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} &=\frac{1}{2} \times 1+1 g[1] \\ g[1] &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 141 The Fourier transform of a signal h(t) is H(j[latex]\omega[/latex]) = (2cos[latex]\omega[/latex])(sin2[latex]\omega[/latex]) /[latex]\omega[/latex]. The value of h(0) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{2 \cos \omega \sin 2 \omega}{\omega}&=H(\omega) \\ H(\omega)=2 \cos \omega&\left(\frac{2 \sin 2 \omega}{2 \omega}-H_{1}(j \omega) \cdot H_{2}(j \omega)\right)\\ \text { where, } \quad H_{1}(j \omega)&=2 \cos \omega\\ H_{2}(j \omega)=\frac{2 \sin 2 \omega}{2 \omega}&=2 \operatorname{Sa}(2 \omega) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] H_{1}(j \omega)=2 \cos \omega=\left(e^{j \omega}+e^{-j \omega}\right)=e^{j \omega t}+e^{j \omega(-1)} [/latex] So [latex] H(j \omega)=2 \cos \omega H_{2}(j \omega)=\left(e^{j \omega}+e^{-j \omega}\right) H_{2}(j \omega) [/latex] [latex] H(j \omega)=e^{j \omega} H_{2}(j \omega)+e^{-j \omega} H_{2}(j \omega) [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad h(t)=h_{2}(t+1)+h_{2}(t-1) [/latex] So, [latex]h(O) = 1[/latex]

question: Question 142 T he input [latex]x(t)[/latex] and output [latex]y(t)[/latex] of a system are related as [latex]y(t)=\int_{-\infty }^{t}x(\tau )cos(3\tau )d\tau[/latex]. The system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y&=\int_{-\infty}^{t} x(\tau) \cos (3 \tau) d \tau \\ y\left(t-t_{0}\right)&=\int_{-\infty}^{t-t_{0}} x(\tau) \cos (3 \tau) d \tau \\ y^{\prime}(t) \text { for input } &x\left(t-t_{0}\right) \text { , is }\\ y^{\prime}(t)&=\int_{-\infty}^{t} x\left(\tau-t_{0}\right) \cos 3 \tau d \tau \\ y^{\prime}(t)&=\int_{-\infty}^{\left(t-t_{0}\right)} x(\tau) \cos 3\left(\tau+t_{0}\right) d \tau \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] y^{\prime}(t) \neq y\left(t-t_{0}\right)[/latex] so system is not time invariant for input [latex]x(\tau)=\cos (3 \tau)[/latex] (bounded input) [latex] y(t)=\int_{-\infty}^{t} \cos ^{2}(3 \tau) d \tau \rightarrow \infty \text { as } t \rightarrow \infty[/latex] So, for bounded i/p, o/p is not bounded therefore system is not stable.

question: Question 143 If [latex]x[n]=(1/3)^{|n|}-(1/2)^{n}u[n][/latex], then the region of convergence (ROC) of its Z-transform in the Z-plane will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x[n]&=\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{|n|}-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} \cup[n] \\ x[n]&=\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{n}u[n]+\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{-n} u[-n-1]-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} u[n] \\ \left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{n} &u[n] \longleftrightarrow \frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{3} z^{-1}} \quad \text{ROC}|z|\gt \frac{1}{3} \\ \left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{-n} &u(-n-1] \longleftrightarrow \frac{-1}{1-3 z^{-1}} \text{ROC}|z| \lt 3 \\ \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} &u[n] \longleftrightarrow \frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{2} z^{-1}} \quad \text{ROC}|z| \gt \frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] So, overall ROC will be intersection of there ROC i.e. [latex] \frac{1}{2}\lt |z| \lt 3[/latex]

question: Question 144 The unilateral Laplace transform of [latex]f(t)[/latex] is [latex]\frac{1}{s^{2}+s+1}[/latex]. The unilateral Laplace transform of [latex]t f(t)[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{If }\quad L[f(t)]&=\bar{f}(s) then\\ L\left[t^{n} f(t)\right]&=(-1)^{n} \frac{d^{n}}{d s^{n}} \bar{f}(s) \end{aligned}[/latex] In this problem, Given, [latex] \begin{aligned} L[f(t)] &=\frac{1}{s^{2}+s+1}=\bar{f}(s) \\ \text { We need } & L[t f(t)]=(-1)^{1} \frac{d^{1}}{d s^{1}} \bar{f}(s) \\ &=-\frac{d}{d s} \bar{f}(s) \\ &=-\frac{d}{d s}\left[\frac{1}{s^{2}+s+1}\right] \\ &=-\left[\frac{-1}{\left(s^{2}+s+1\right)^{2}}\right] \times(2 s+1) \\ &=\left[\frac{2 s+1}{\left(s^{2}+s+1\right)^{2}}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 145 The first six points of the 8-point DFT of a real valued sequence are 5, 1-j3, 0, 3-j4, 0 and 3+j4. The last two points of the DFT are respectively
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x[n] &\rightarrow \text{ real}\\ X[k] &\rightarrow \text{Conjugate symmetric }\\ \Rightarrow \quad X[k]&=X^{*}[N-k] \\ N &=8 \\ X[k]&=X^{*}[8-k] \\ \therefore \quad X[6]&=X^{*}[8-6]=X^{*}[2]=0 \\ X[7]&=X^{*}[8-7]=X^{*}[1]=1+j 3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 146 Two systems [latex]H_{1}(z)[/latex] and [latex]H_{2}(z)[/latex] are connected in cascade as shown below. The overall output [latex]y(n)[/latex] is the same as the input [latex]x(n)[/latex] with a one unit delay. The
transfer function of the second system [latex]H_{2}(z)[/latex] is
solution: [latex]y[n]=x[n-1][/latex] Taking z-transform of both sides [latex] \begin{aligned} r(z) &=z^{-1} X(z) \\ \frac{\gamma(z)}{X(z)} &=z^{-1} \end{aligned}[/latex] For cascaded system [latex] \begin{aligned} H(z)&=H_{1}(z) \cdot H_{2}(z)\\ z^{-1} &=\frac{\left(1-0.4 z^{-1}\right)}{\left(1-0.6 z^{-1}\right)^{-1}(z)} \\ \therefore \quad H_{2}(z) &=\frac{z^{-1}\left(1-0.6 z^{-1}\right)}{\left(1-0.4 z^{-1}\right)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 147 If [latex]F(s)=L[f(t)]=\frac{2(s+1)}{s^{2}+4s+7}[/latex] then the initial and final values of [latex]f(t)[/latex] are respectively
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F(s)&=L[f(t)]=\frac{2(s+1)}{s^{2}+4 s+7}\\ \text{Initial value,}\\ \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} f(t) &=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} s F(s)=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} s \cdot \frac{2(s+1)}{s^{2}+4 s+7} \\ &=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2 s^{2}\left(1+\frac{1}{s}\right)}{s^{2}\left(1+\frac{4}{s}+\frac{7}{s^{2}}\right)} \\ &=\frac{2(1+0)}{(1+0+0)}=2\\ \text{Final value,}\\ \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} f(t) &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s F(s)=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s \cdot \frac{2(s+1)}{s^{2}+4 s+7} \\ &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 148 An input x(t)=exp(-2t)u(t)+[latex]\delta[/latex](t-6) is applied to an LTI system with
impulse response h(t)=u(t). The output is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t)&=e^{-2 t} u(t)+\delta(t-6) \\ x(s)&=\frac{1}{s+2}+e^{-6 s} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} & H(s)=\frac{1}{s} \\ \therefore \quad & Y(s)=X(s) \cdot H(s) \\ \Rightarrow \quad & Y(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+2)}+\frac{1}{s} e^{-6 s} \\ \Rightarrow \quad & Y(s)=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{s+2}\right)+\frac{1}{s} e^{-6 s} \\ \text { Taking inverse }&\text{Laplace transform, we have } \\ & y(t)=0.5\left(1-e^{-2 t}\right) u(t)+u(t-6) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 149 The trigonometric Fourier series of an even function does not have the
solution:
Trigonometric Fourier series of an even function
has de and cosine terms only.

question: Question 150 If the unit step response of a network is [latex](1-e^{-at})[/latex], then its unit impulse response is
solution: Unit step response [latex] s(t)=\left(1-e^{-\alpha t}\right) [/latex] So, unit impulse response is [latex] \begin{aligned} h(t) &=\frac{d s(t)}{d t}=\frac{d}{d t}\left(1-e^{-\alpha t}\right) \\ &=\alpha e^{-\alpha t} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 151 A system is defined by its impulse response [latex]h(n) =2^{n} u(n - 2)[/latex]. The system is
solution: [latex]h(n)=2^{n} u(n-2)[/latex] For causal system [latex]h(n)=0[/latex] for [latex] n \lt 0 [/latex] Hence given system is causal. For stability: [latex] \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} 2^{n}=\infty,[/latex] so given system is not stable.

question:
Question 152 The transfer function of a discrete time LTI system is given by [latex]H(z)=\frac{2-\frac{3}{4}z^{-1}}{1-\frac{3}{4}z^{-1}+\frac{1}{8}z^{-2}}[/latex] Consider the following statements: S1: The system is stable and causal for ROC: |z| [latex]\gt[/latex]
 1/2 S2: The system is stable but not causal for ROC:| z| [latex]\lt[/latex]
1/4 S3: The system is neither stable nor causal for ROC: 1/4 [latex]\lt[/latex]
 |z| [latex]\lt[/latex]
 1/2 Which one of the following statements is valid ?
solution:
A discrete-time LTI system is causal if and 
only if the ROC of its system function is the 
exterior of a circle, including infinity. A discrete-time LTI system is stable if and only 
if the ROC of its system function includes the 
unit circle,  [latex]|z|=1 [/latex] [latex]
 H(z)=\begin{array}{l}\left(1-\frac{1}{4} z^{-1}\right)+\left(1-\frac{1}{2} z^{-1}\right) \\ \left(1-\frac{1}{4} z^{-1}\right)\left(1-\frac{1}{2} z^{-1}\right)\end{array} [/latex] or  [latex]H(z)=\frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{4} z^{-1}}+\frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{2} z^{-1}} [/latex] For  [latex]\mathrm{ROC}:|z| \gt \frac{1}{2},[/latex] the system is stable and 
causal. For  [latex]\mathrm{ROC}:|z| \lt \frac{1}{4}, [/latex] ROC  does not include unit
circle. So, system is not stable. For  [latex]ROC: \frac{1}{4} \lt |z| \lt \frac{1}{2},[/latex] ROC  does not include 
unit circle. So, system is not stable.
Also ROC  is not the exterior of  [latex]|z|=\frac{1}{2}[/latex] .So,  it is not causal.

options.A: Both S1 and S2 are true
options.B: Both S2 and S3 are true
options.C: Both S1 and S3 are true

question: Question 153 A continuous time LTI system is described by [latex]\frac{d^{2}y(t)}{dt^{2}}+4\frac{dy(t)}{dt}+3y(t)=2\frac{dx(t)}{dt}+4x(t)[/latex] Assuming zero initial conditions, the response y(t) of the above system for the input [latex]x(t)=e^{-2t}u(t)[/latex] is given by
solution: [latex]\frac{d^{2} y(t)}{d t^{2}}+\frac{4 d y(t)}{d t}+3 y(t)=\frac{2 d x(t)}{d t}+4 x(t) [/latex] Taking Laplace transform on both sides (assuming zero initial conditions). [latex] \begin{aligned} s^{2} Y(s)+4 s Y(s)+3 Y(s)&=2 s X(s)+4 X(s) \\ \text{or }\quad \frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}&=\frac{2 s+4}{s^{2}+4 s+3} \\ &=\frac{2(s+2)}{(s+1)(s+3)} \end{aligned}[/latex] Given that [latex] \begin{aligned} x(t) &=e^{2 t} u(t) \\ x(s) &=\frac{1}{s+2} \\ Y(s) &=\frac{2(s+2)}{(s+1)(s+3)(s+2)} \\ &=\frac{2}{(s+1)(s+3)} \\ &=\frac{1}{s+1}-\frac{1}{s+3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking inverse Laplace transform on both sides. [latex] y(t)=(e^{-t}-e^{-3t})u(t)[/latex]

question: Question 154 Given [latex]f(t)=l^{-1}[\frac{3s+1}{s^{3}+4s^{2}+(K-3)s}]. [/latex] If [latex] \lim_{t\rightarrow \infty }f(t)=1[/latex], then the value of K is
solution: [latex]\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} f(t)=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s F(s) [/latex] Given that, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \quad F(s)=\left[\frac{3 s+1}{s^{3}+4 s^{2}+(K-3) s}\right] \\ \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} f(t)=1 \\ \Rightarrow \lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s\left[\frac{3 s+1}{s^{3}+4 s^{2}+(K-3) s}\right]=1 \\ \Rightarrow \lim _{s \rightarrow 0}\left[\frac{3 s+1}{s^{2}+4 s+(K-3)}\right]=1 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{K-3}=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad k-3=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad K=4 \\ \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 156 Two discrete time system with impulse response [latex]h_{1}[n]=\delta [n-1] [/latex] and [latex] h_{2}[n]=\delta [n-2][/latex] are connected in cascade. The overall impulse response of the cascaded system is

[latex] h[n]=\delta(n-3)[/latex]

question: Question 158 The trigonometric Fourier series for the waveform [latex]f(t)[/latex] shown below contains
solution:
since  f(t) is an even function, its trigonometric 
Fourier series contains only cosine terms. D.C. component, [latex]
 \begin{aligned} A_{0} &=\frac{1}{T} \int_{-T / 2}^{T / 2} f(t) d t=\frac{2}{T} \int_{0}^{T / 2} f(t) d t \\ &=\frac{2}{T}\left[\int_{0}^{T / 4} A d t+\int_{T / 4}^{T / 2}(-2 A) d t\right] \\ &=\frac{2}{T}\left[\frac{A T}{4}-2 A\left(\frac{T}{2}-\frac{T}{4}\right)\right] \\ &=\frac{2}{T}\left[-\frac{A T}{4}\right]=-\frac{A}{2} \end{aligned} [/latex] Therefore, the trigonometric Fourier series for the 
waveform f(t) contains only cosine terms and a 
negative value for the dc component.

question:
Question 159 An LTI system having transfer function [latex]\frac{s^{2}+1}{s^{2}+2s+1}[/latex]
 and input [latex]x(t) = sin(t+1)[/latex] is in steady state. The output is sampled at a rate [latex]\omega_{s}[/latex]  rad/s to obtain the final output {y(k)}. Which of the following is true ?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t) &=\sin (t+1) \\ \omega  &=1 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \\ X(s) &=\frac{\omega }{(\omega )^{2}+s^{2}} \cdot e^{s}=\frac{1}{1^{2}+s^{2}} \theta^{s}=\frac{e^{s}}{s^{2}+1} \\ H(s) &=\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)} \\ Y(s) &=H(s) X(s)\\ Y(s)&=\frac{s^{2}+1}{s^{2}+2 s+1} \times \frac{e^{s}}{s^{2}+1}=\frac{e^{s}}{s^{2}+2 s+1}\\ Y(s)&=\frac{e^{s}}{(s+1)^{2}} \\ y(t) &=(t+1) e^{(t+1)} \\ y(\infty) &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s Y(s)=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{s e^{s}}{(s+1)^{2}}=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] So, at steady state y remains zero for all sampling frequencies [latex] \omega_{S}[/latex]

options.A: y(.) is zero for all sampling frequencies [latex]\omega _{s}[/latex]
options.B: y(.) is nonzero for all sampling frequencies [latex]\omega _{s} [/latex]
options.C: y(.) is nonzero for [latex]\omega _{s} \gt 2[/latex]  , but zero for [latex]\omega _{s} \lt 2[/latex]
options.D: y(.) is zero for [latex]\omega _{s} \gt 2[/latex], but nonzero for [latex]\omega _{s} \lt 2[/latex]

question: Question 160 The 4-point Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) of a discrete time sequence {1,0,2,3} is
solution: 4-point OFT of sequence {1, 0, 2, 3} is given as [latex] \begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -j & -1 & j \\ 1 & -1 & 1 & -1 \\ 1 & j & -1 & -j \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c} 1+2+3 \\ 1-2+3 j \\ 1+2-3 \\ 1-2-3 j \end{array}\right]\\ =\left[\begin{array}{c} 6 \\ -1+3 j \\ 0 \\ -1-3 j \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 167 The impulse response h(t) of a linear time invariant continuous time system is
given by h(t)=exp(-2t)u(t), where u(t) denotes the unit step function The output of this system, to the sinusoidal input x(t)=2cos(2t) for all time t, is
solution: Input [latex]x(t)=2 \cos (2 t) [/latex] Frequency response [latex] \begin{aligned} X(\omega)&=2 \pi[\delta(\omega-2)+\delta(\omega+2)]\\ H(\omega)&=\frac{1}{2+j \omega} \\ \text{output}\quad Y(\omega)&=H(\omega) X(\omega) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{1}{2+j \omega} \cdot 2 \pi[\delta(\omega-2)+\delta(\omega+2)] \\ =\frac{2 \pi}{2+j 2} \delta(\omega-2)+\frac{2 \pi}{2-j 2} \delta(\omega+2) \\ =\frac{2 \pi}{8}[(2-j 2) \delta(\omega-2)+(2+j 2) \delta(\omega+2)] \\ \left.=\frac{\pi}{4}[2\{\delta(\omega-2)+\delta(\omega+2)\}+j 2\{\delta(\omega)+2)-\delta(\omega-2)\}\right] \\ =\frac{\pi}{2}[\delta(\omega-2)+\delta(\omega+2)]-j \frac{\pi}{2}[\delta(\omega-2)-\delta(\omega+2)] \\ \therefore \quad y(t)=\frac{\cos 2 t}{2}+\frac{\sin 2 t}{2} \\ =\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cos 2 t+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin 2 t\right] \\ =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cos (2 t-0.25 \pi) \\ =2^{-0.5} \cos (2 t-0.25 \pi) \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 168 The impulse response h(t) of a linear time invariant continuous time system is
given by h(t)=exp(-2t)u(t), where u(t) denotes the unit step function The frequency response H([latex]\omega[/latex]) of this system in terms of angular frequency [latex]\omega[/latex], is given by H([latex]\omega[/latex])=
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h(t) &=\exp (-2 t) u(t) \\ H(\omega) &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} h(t) e^{-j \omega t} d t \\ &=\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-2 t} e^{-j \omega t} d t=\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-(2+j \omega) t} d t \\ &=-\left.\frac{1}{2+j \omega} \cdot e^{-(2+j \omega) t}\right|_{0} \\ &=\frac{1}{2+j \omega} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 174 The signal x(t) is described by [latex]x(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1 &for -1\leq t\leq +1 \\ 0& otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] Two of the angular frequencies at which its Fourier transform becomes zero are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} X(\omega) &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x(t) e^{-j \omega t} d t \\ &=\int_{-1}^{1} e^{-j \omega t} d t=\left.\frac{e^{-j \omega t}}{-j \omega}\right|_{-1} ^{1} \\ &=\frac{e^{-j \omega}}{-j \omega}-\frac{e^{j \omega}}{-j \omega}\\ &=\frac{1}{j \omega}\left(e^{i 0}-e^{-j \omega}\right) \\ X(\omega) &=0 \\ \Rightarrow e^{j \omega}-e^{-i \omega} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow e^{j \omega}-\frac{1}{e^{i \omega}} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad e^{2 i \omega}-1 &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad e^{2 j \omega}&=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad e^{i \omega}&=\pm 1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \omega &=\pi, 2 \pi \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 178 A 5-point sequence x[n]  is given as x[-3]=1, x[-2]=1,  x[-1]=0, x[0]=5 and x[1]=1. Let [latex]X(e^{j\omega })[/latex] denoted the discrete-time Fourier transform of x[n]. The value of [latex]\int_{-\pi }^{\pi }X(e^{j\omega })d\omega[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} X\left(e^{j \omega}\right)&=e^{3 / \omega}+e^{2 / \omega}+0+5+e^{-j \omega} \\ \because\quad \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} e^{z i \omega} d \omega&=0 \text { if } a \neq 0 \\ \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} X\left(e^{i \omega}\right) & d \omega=\left|\frac{e^{3 / \omega}}{3 j}+\frac{e^{2 j \omega}}{2 j}+5 \omega+\frac{e^{-j \omega}}{-j}\right|_{-\pi}^{\pi} \\ &=5 \pi+5 \pi=10 \pi \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 189 A sequence x(n) has non-zero values as shown in figure. The Fourier transform of y(2n) will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y(2 n)&=x(n-1),\text{ seeing in graph}\\ f(n) &=y(2 n) \\ = \frac{1}{2} \delta(n+1)&+\delta(n)+2 \delta(n-1)+\delta(n-2)+\frac{1}{2} \delta(n-3) \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking z-transform [latex] \begin{aligned} F(z)&=\frac{1}{2} z+1+2 z^{-1}+z^{-2}+\frac{1}{2} z^{-3} \\ Z &=e^{j \omega} \\ F\left(e^{j \omega}\right) &=\frac{1}{2} e^{j \omega}+1+2 e^{-j \omega}+e^{-2 j \omega}+\frac{1}{2} e^{-3 j \omega} \\ &=e^{-j \omega}\left(\frac{1}{2} e^{2 j \omega}+e^{j \omega}+2+e^{-j \omega}+\frac{1}{2} e^{-2 j \omega}\right) \\ &=e^{-j \omega\left[\frac{e^{2 j \omega}+e^{-2 j \omega}}{2}+e^{j \omega}+e^{-j \omega}+2\right]} \\ f(n) &=e^{-j \omega}[\cos 2 \omega+2 \cos \omega+2] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 190 A sequence x(n) has non-zero values as shown in figure. The sequence [latex]y(n)=\left\{\begin{matrix} X(\frac{n}{2}-1), & For \;  n \;  is \; even\\ 0, & For \; n \; is \; odd \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] will be

question: Question 192 A signal [latex]x(n)=sin(\omega _{0}n+\phi )[/latex] is the input to a linear time- invariant system having a frequency response H([latex]e^{j\omega }[/latex]). If the output of the system Ax(n - [latex]n_{0}[/latex]) then the most general form of [latex]\angle H(e^{j\omega })[/latex] will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sin \left(\omega_{0} n+\phi\right) &=x(n) \leftrightarrow X\left(\mathrm{e}^{j \omega}\right) \\ y(n) &=A x\left(n-n_{o}\right) \\ \left(e^{i \omega}\right) &=A e^{-j \omega} X\left(e^{i \omega}\right) \\ H\left(e^{i \omega}\right) &=\frac{Y\left(e^{j \omega}\right)}{X\left(e^{j\omega}\right)}=A e^{-j n_{u} \omega}\\ \angle H\left(e^{j \omega}\right)&=-n_{o} \omega_{o}+2 \pi k \quad\left(\text { at } \omega=\omega_{o}\right) \end{aligned}\\[/latex]

Question 194 The output y(t) of a linear time invariant system is related to its input x(t) by
the following equations: [latex]y(t)=0.5x(t-t_{d}+T)+x(t-t_{d})[/latex] [latex]+0.5x(t-t_{d}+T)[/latex] The filter transfer function H([latex]\omega[/latex]) of such a system is given by
solution: [latex]y(t)=0.5 x\left(t-t_{d}+T\right)+0.5 x\left(t-t_{d}-T\right)+x\left(t-t_{d}\right) [/latex] Taking Fourier transform [latex] \begin{aligned} Y(\omega)&=\left[0.5 e^{j \omega\left(-t_{d}+T\right)}+0.5 e^{j \omega\left(-t_{d}+T \right)}+e^{-j \omega t_{d}}\right] X(\omega) \\ \frac{Y(\omega)}{X(\omega)}&=e^{-j \omega t_{d}}\left[0.5 e^{j \omega T}+0.5 e^{-j\omega T}+1\right] \\ \frac{Y(\omega)}{X(\omega)}&=e^{-j \omega t} [\cos \omega T+1] \\ H(\omega)&=(1+\cos \omega T) e^{-j \omega t_d} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 197 Let [latex]x(n)=(\frac{1}{2})^{n}u(n), \; y(n)=x^{2}(n)[/latex] and [latex]Y(e^{j\omega })[/latex] be the Fourier transform of y(n) then Y [latex](e^{j0})[/latex]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(n)&=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} \cdot u(n) \\ y(n)&=x^{2}(n)=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2 n} u^{2}(n) \\ y(n)&=\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{n} u(n) \\ Y(z)&=\frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{4} z^{-1}} \\ \text{Put, }z=e^{j \omega}& \\ Y\left(e^{i \omega}\right)=&\frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{4} e^{-j \omega}} ; \\ Y\left(e^{j 0}\right)&=\frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{4}}=\frac{4}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 203 The impulse response h[n] of a linear time invariant system is given as [latex]\left\{\begin{matrix} -2\sqrt{2} & n=1,-1\\ 4\sqrt{2} & n=2,-2\\ 0& otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] If the input to the above system is the sequence [latex]e^{j\pi n/4}[/latex], then the output is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h(n)&= 4 \sqrt{2} \delta(n+2)-2 \sqrt{2} \delta(n+1) \\ &-2 \sqrt{2} \delta(n-1)+4 \sqrt{2} \delta(n-2) \\ x(n)&=e^{j \pi n / 4} \\ y(n)&= x(n)^{*} h(n) \\ &=4 \sqrt{2} \delta(n+2)^{*} e^{j n \pi / 4}+4 \sqrt{2} \delta(n-2)^{*} e^{i \pi / 4} \\ &-2 \sqrt{2}\left[\delta(n+1)^{*} e^{j m / 4}+\delta(n-1) e^{j m / 4}\right] \\ &\quad x(n)^{\star} \delta(n-a) \rightarrow x(n-a) \\ &y(n)=4 \sqrt{2}\left[e^{j \pi / 4(n+2)}+e^{j \pi / 4(n-2)}\right] \\ &\quad -2 \sqrt{2}\left[e^{j \pi / 4(n+1)}+e^{j \pi / 4(n-0)}\right] \\ &=e^{j n \pi / 4}\left[4 \sqrt{2}\left(e^{j \pi / 2}+e^{-j \pi / 2}\right)\right] \\ &\quad -2 \sqrt{2}\left(e^{i \pi / 4}+e^{-j \pi / 4}\right) \\ &=e^{i n / 4}[0-2 \sqrt{2} \times 2 \cos \pi / 4] \\ y(n)&=-4 e^{i n \pi / 4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 204 A causal LTI system is described by the difference equation 2y[n]=ay[n-2]-2x[n]+bx[n-1] The system is stable only if
solution: [latex]2 y[n]=\alpha y[n-2]-2 x[n]+\beta x[n-1][/latex] Taking z-transform [latex] \begin{array}{c} 2 Y(z)=\alpha Y(z) z^{2}-2 X(z)+\beta X(z) z^{-1} \\ Y z)\left[2-\alpha z^{2}\right]=X(z)\left[\beta z^{-1}-2\right] \\ \frac{Y(z)}{X(z)}=\left(\begin{array}{c} \beta z^{-1}-2 \\ 2-\alpha z^{-2} \end{array}\right) \end{array}[/latex] For system to be stable, [latex]\beta[/latex] can be of any value. [latex] \begin{aligned} 2-\alpha z^{-2} &=0 \\ 2 z^{2}-\alpha &=0 \\ z &=\sqrt{\frac{\alpha}{2}} \lt 1 \\ |\alpha| & \lt 2 \end{aligned}[/latex] For system to be stable all poles should be inside unity circle.

question: Question 210 The impulse response h[n] of a linear time-invariant system is given by h[n]=u[n+3] + u[n-2) - 2n[n-7] where u[n] is the unit step sequence. The above system is

So system is stable. Response depends on future value of input signal i.e. u(n + 3). So, system is not causal

Let [latex]t_{g}(f)[/latex] be the group delay function of the given RC-LPF and [latex]f_{2}[/latex] = 100 Hz. Then [latex]t_{g}(f_{2})[/latex] in ms, is

Question 213 The system under consideration is an RC low-pass filter (RC-LPF) with R = 1 k[latex]\Omega[/latex] and C = 1.0 [latex]\mu[/latex]F. Let H(f) denote the frequency response of the RC-LPF. Let [latex]f_{1}[/latex] be the highest frequency such that [latex]0\leq \left | f \right |\leq f_{1}, \; \frac{\left | H\left ( f_{1} \right ) \right |}{H(0)}\geq 0.95[/latex]. Then [latex]f_{1}[/latex] (in Hz) is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \begin{aligned} H(f)&=\frac{1}{1+j 2 \pi f R C}\\ H(0) &=1 \\ \frac{\left|H\left(f_{1}\right)\right|}{H(0)} &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+4 \pi^{2} f_{1}^{2} R^{2} C^{2}}} \geq 0.95 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{1+4 \pi^{2} f_{1}^{2}(R C)^{2}} & \leq 0.9025 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1.108 & \leq 1+4 \pi^{2} f_{1}^{2}(R C)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.108 & \geq 4 \pi^{2} f_{1}^{2}(R C)^{2} \\ f_{1}^{2} \leq & \frac{0.108}{4 \pi^{2}(R C)^{2}} \\ f_{1} & \leq \frac{0.329}{2 \pi \times 10^{-3}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad f_{1 \max } &=52.2 \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 214 Let P be linearity, Q be time-invariance, R be causality and S be stability. A discrete time system has the input-output relationship, [latex]y(n)=\left\{\begin{matrix} x(n) &n\geq 1 \\ 0, &n=0 \\ x(n+1)&n\leq -1 \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] where x(n) is the input and y(n) is the output. The above system has the properties
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y\left(n-n_{0}\right)&=x\left(n-n_{0}+1\right)(\text { time varying })\\ y(n)&=x(n+1) \text{(depends on future)} \\ \text{i.e.}\quad y(1)&=x(2) \quad \text{(non causal) } \end{aligned}[/latex] For bounded input, system has bounded output. So it is stable. [latex] \begin{aligned} y(n) &=x(n), n \geq 1 \\ &=0, n=0 \\ &=x(n+1), n \leq-1 \end{aligned}[/latex] So, system is linear.

options.A: P, S but not Q, R
options.B: P, Q, S but not R
options.D: Q, R, S but not P

question: Question 215 A sequence x(n) with the z-transform [latex]X(z) = z^{4}+z^{2}-2z+2-3z^{-4}[/latex] is applied as an input to a linear, time-invariant system with the impulse response [latex]h(n) =2 \delta (n - 3)[/latex] where [latex]\delta (n)=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1, &n=0 \\ 0, &otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] The output at n = 4 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Y(z) &=H(z) X(z) \\ H(z) &=2 z^{-3} \\ \therefore Y(z) &=2 z^{3}\left(z^{4}+z^{2}-2 z+2-3 z^{-4}\right) \\ &=2\left(z+z^{-1}-2 z^{2}+2 z^{3}-3 z^{7}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking inverse of z -transform [latex] \begin{aligned} y(n)=& 2[\delta(n+1)+\delta(n-1)-2 \delta(n-2)\\ &+2 \delta(n-3)-3 \delta(n-7)]\\ \text{At }n&=4, y(4)=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 216 Let x(t) be the input to a linear, time-invariant system. The required output is 4x(t-2). The transfer function of the system should be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y(t) &=4 x(t-2) \\ Y(s) &=4 e^{-2 s} X(s) \\ \frac{Y(s)}{X(s)} &=4 e^{-2 s} \\ H(f) &=4 e^{-2 x j .2 \pi t}=4 e^{-j 4 \pi t} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 217 The Fourier series expansion of a real periodic signal with fundamental frequency [latex]f_{0}[/latex] is given by [latex]g_{p}(t)=\sum_{n=-\infty }^{\infty}c_{n}e^{j2\pi  nf_{0}t}[/latex]. It is given that [latex]c_{3}=3+j5[/latex]. Then [latex]c_{-3}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} c_{-k}=c_{k}^{*} \\ c_{3}=3+j 5 \\ c_{-3}=c_{k}^{*}=3-j 5 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 218 The Laplace transform of i(t) is given by [latex]I(s)=\frac{2}{s\left ( 1+s \right )}[/latex] At [latex]t\rightarrow \infty[/latex] The value of i(t) tends to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} i(t) &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s I(s) \\ &=\operatorname{lims}_{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{2}{s(1+s)}=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 219 If the impulse response of a discrete-time system is [latex]h[n]=-5^{n}u[-n-1][/latex], then
the system function H(z) is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h(n) &= -5^{n}u[- n-1] \\ H(z) &=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} h(n) z^{-n} \\ H(z) &=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{-1}-5^{n} z^{-n}, \text { Let } n=-k \\ &=-\sum_{n=\infty}^{1}\left(5 z^{-1}\right)^{-k} \\ &=1-\sum_{K=0}^{\infty}\left(5^{-1} z\right)^{k} \\ &=1-\frac{1}{1-5^{-1} z}, \; \left|5^{-1} z\right| \lt 1 , \; |z| \lt 5 \mid \\ &=1-\frac{5}{5-z} \\ &=-\frac{z}{5-z}=\frac{z}{z-5} \end{aligned} [/latex] The system is stable because ROC includes unit circle.

question: Question 220 The Laplace transform of a continuous-time signal x(t) is [latex]X(s)=\frac{5-s}{s^{2}-s-2}[/latex]. If the Fourier transform of this signal exists, then x(t) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(s) &=\frac{5-s}{s^{2}-s-2}=\frac{5-s}{(s+1)(s-2)} \\ \frac{5-s}{(s+1)(s-2)} &=\frac{A}{s+1}+\frac{B}{s-2} \\ 5-s &=A(s-2)+B(s+1) \\ s &=2,3=3 B \\ \Rightarrow \quad B &=1 \\ s &=-1,6=-3 A \\ \Rightarrow \quad A &=-2 \\ x(t) &=-2 e^{-1} u(t)-e^{2 t} u(-t) \\ \therefore &=-1 \lt \sigma \lt 2 \end{aligned} [/latex] Note: ROC of Laplace transform should include [latex] \sigma=0[/latex] line.

question: Question 221 A linear phase channel with phase delay [latex]T_{P}[/latex] and group delay [latex]T_{g}[/latex] must have
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta(\omega) &=-\omega \zeta_{0} \\ T_{p} &=\frac{-\theta(\omega)}{\omega}=T_{0} \\ T_{g} &=-\cdot \frac{d \theta(\omega)}{d \omega}=T_{0} \\ T_{p} &=T_{g}=T_{0}=\text { constant } \end{aligned}[/latex]'

question: Question 222 The Fourier transform [latex]F\{e^{-1}u(t)\}[/latex] is equal to [latex]\frac{1}{1+j2\pi f}[/latex]. therefore, [latex] F\{\frac{1}{1+j2\pi t}\}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(t) &=e^{-t} u(t) \\ F(t) &=\frac{1}{1+j 2 \pi f}\\ \text { From duality, } &F(t) \stackrel{F T}{\leftarrow\longrightarrow}{f(-f)}\\ \Rightarrow \quad F(t)&=\frac{1}{1+\mathrm{j} 2 \pi t} \\ f(-f)&=e^{f} u(-f) \\ F(t) &\stackrel{F T}{\leftarrow\longrightarrow} e^{f} u(-f) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 223 Which of the following cannot be the Fourier series expansion of a periodic
signal?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t) &=2 \cos \pi t+7 \cos t \\ T_{1} &=\frac{2 \pi}{(0)}=2 \\ T_{2} &=\frac{2 \pi}{1}=2 \pi \\ \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}} &=\frac{1}{\pi}=\text { irrational } \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore x(t)[/latex] is not periodic and does not satisfy Dirichlet condition.

question: Question 224 Convolution of x(t+5) with impulse function [latex]\delta[/latex](t-7) is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t+5) * \delta(t-7) &=x(t+5-7) \\ &=x(t-2) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 225 The impulse response functions of four linear systems S1, S2, S3, S4 are given
respectively by [latex]h_{1}(t)=1[/latex] [latex]h_{2}(t)=U(t)[/latex] [latex]h_{3}(t)=\frac{U(t)}{t+1}[/latex] [latex]h_{4}(t)=e^{-3t}U(t)[/latex] where U(t) is the step function. Which of these systems is time invariant, causal and stable?
solution: [latex]h_{1}(t) \neq 0 \text { for } t\lt 0 [/latex] Therefores, is non causal [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{2}(t)&=u(t)=0 \text { for } t \lt 0 \\ \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} n_{2}(t) d t&=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} u(t) d t=\int_{0}^{\infty} d t=\infty \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore [latex]s_{2}[/latex] is unstable and causal [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{3}(t)&=\frac{u(t)}{t+1} \\ \text { at } t&=-1 \\ h_{f}(t)&=\infty, h_{3}(t)=0 \text { for } t \lt 0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore [latex]s_{3}[/latex] is unstable and causal [latex] h_{4}(t)=e^{-3 t} u(t)[/latex] [latex] s_{4}[/latex] is time invariant, causal and stable

question: Question 226 If a signal f(t) has energy E, the energy of the signal f(2t) is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t)^{2} d t \\ E^{\prime} &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(2 t)^{2} d t \\ &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(p)^{2}-\frac{d p}{2}\left(2 t=p ; d t=\frac{d p}{2}\right) \\ E^{\prime} &=\frac{E}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 227 Let [latex]\delta(t)[/latex] denote the delta function. The value of the integral [latex]\int_{-\infty }^{\infty}\delta (t)\cos \left ( \frac{3t}{2} \right )dt[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \delta(t) \cos \left(\frac{3 t}{2}\right) d t=f(0)=\cos \left(\frac{3 \times 0}{2}\right)=\cos 0=1[/latex]

question: Question 228 The region of convergence of the z-transform of a unit step function is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h(n)&=u(n) \\ H(z)&=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} 1 . z^{-n} \end{aligned}[/latex] For the convergence of H(z) [latex] \sum_{n=0}^{n}\left(z^{-1}\right)^{n}\lt \infty[/latex] \therefore ROC is the range of values of z for which [latex] \left|z^{-1}\right| \lt 1\text{ or } |z|\gt |1|[/latex]

question:
Question 229 The transfer function of a system is given by [latex]H(s)=\frac{1}{s^2(s-2)}[/latex]. The impulse
response of the system is: (* denotes convolution, and U(t) is unit step function)
solution: Impulse response of system is [latex]L^{-1}[H(s)] [/latex] [latex] \frac{1}{s^{2}(s-2)}=\frac{1}{s^{2}} \times \frac{1}{s-2}=\left(t * e^{+2 t}\right) u(t)[/latex]
